Everyone, listen to @montabe, he's a smart dude!
isn't software the only thing that is "protected" by both copyright and patents?
@johnbellone I still go to the movie theater for those :)
@johnbellone I know, I'm not the typical use case, but I've seen the future and can't go back, I'm sure everything will go that way eventually. It's just going to take another 10 or 20 years.
@joefiorini The trick (in my case), is ignoring traditional startups. Charge money, and build it to the point it can become a the main job.
I've found it takes longer to find a partner. I have enough ideas to drown Rhode Island.
@joefiorini Betamax became the film industry's technology vendor, they basically got that entire market to themselves. Tons of money, whereas VHS became mainstream and budgetized.
@KuraFire 7.1 digital surround sound, 1080p, show me :)
@kurafire Interesting, there could be a great documentary in that!
@johnbellone BluRay will die. As audio/video codecs get better and online streaming becomes more common it will replace discs.
@joefiorini or a very understanding family
@johnbellone I'm solo. It slows me down, but I'm further now than I would be if I waited to find a cofounder

Marshal, nice

@joefiorini Yeah, the workflow doesnt make a ton of sense for those of us with kids.
Seams like visions of ruling the human raise are bad... just me?

The key advice I have: I'm you're single, or at least without kids, do it now. Quit your job, pour yourself into it and live off bologna and ramen for a while. You're never going to be in a better position.
@montabe Yes.
@montabe but how do you avoid sucking at both?
I think Leah's talk is geared towards people with no responsibilities outside of work
@johnbellone why do you need a partner?
@johnbellone  @hdyar Streaming is already replacing it for countless of people. Ask Netflix, Amazon and Apple about their download & streaming numbers.
@joefiorini I wouldn't say that. I built http://typealoud.com basics while working.
it just takes a lot longer to find the idea, you can't work on the first thing that comes to your mind
@nathanwdavis My plan for TA was to give away an Amazon Kindle randomly to the people that filled out my feed back forms.
@swilliams_et encode a video bitstream into a vinyl LP
@joefiorini I have a day job and two kids. And a side business. It can be done; it's all a matter of priorities.
@montabe do you think the side business will take over the day job eventually?
<3 Lego X-men
You have to quit your day job before your side business will turn into a real business
What else do you call it?
Method/process.
Question: What do you do to get good user feedback while your user-base is still small?
@montabe fair enough, I just find it tough to get the right balance. Sounds like "practice" is the best way to find it
@johnbellone @netshade - omg, oembed is totally still around. Twitter uses it for their sidebar!
@JacobCheezburger lodsys would disagree :-/
@montabe Will your side project ever get to the point of supporting you without you being able to spend all your time on it?
ideas aren't worth anything until you act on them, but every great product starts with an idea
patents*
@montabe one disadvantage: you spend a ton of time away from family working on your side business

@joefiorini I'm in general agreement. This stays a side project until it can support my family and I. I pour as much as much as I can into it right now, but it's going to remain a side business until that point; then we get to a real business with full-time resources. I have a wife, kids, a mortgage; it's unwise to burn the only boat we have.
@montabe yep, agreed

And the other thing: What you build today is better than what you start building five months from now. It'll be at least five months better. You need feedback more than anything else. Get it done; get it shipped and work your ass off.

@montabe I agree to an extent. I feel like there will come a point where I have to take a big risk to make my startup support us. I'm just trying to make sure we have a safety net so I can take that risk.
Hm, nice core use case @leah, but kind of puts you into the realm of Stack Overflow?
is it still a side project if it is making some money or achieving it's goal without paying your mortgage?
Does anyone on convore want to give me some developer support?
Awesome
meaning when do you start calling it a business?
hire a lawyer
Ah. "side project" v. "side business" ;-)
@_JConner so true
Copyright is the actual implementation, patent is the method
cough Lodsys cough
Cough *Lodsys* cough
MVP should be first.
@joefiorini At some point. That requires enough growth to a) hire myself and then b) hire people I trust.
@leah I am a fan of anonymous statistics as much as possible. And if I can't do that I usually only ask one question.
This trough of sorrow sounds a lot of a mental state. Once you have momentum you'll find ways to climb out, or go bust.
@netshade I was planning on using oembed spec after I talked with @leah in NYC when she presented it once. But I never heard anything more.
@michaelfox I don't know the answer to that. I just try my best not to. Wish I had better advice than that.
I think oembed went underground... I agree with you, @netshade, that it's not really very controversial
@johnbellone that sounds like a really good idea... I'm curious what you come up with :)
@nathanwdavis Give shit away for free.
@joefiorini there are plenty of people who do YC that have kids. I think they Skype a lot :D
@leah With their kids? <kidding>
I'd love to hear someone talk (or blog) about doing a startup when they have family + kids... I'd find that super interesting and probably quite informative
i agree, i would love to do a start up but i love my wife and kid more
@johnbellone I really like Stack Overflow and I probably didn't explain the new pivot very well - it's not really like Stack Overflow at all (actually less like it than the current convore)
although... you don't actually need to be a corporation... it's good for legal reasons, but being a sole incorporator doesn't require you to do anything (yay!)
I'd be happy to chat more about it later ;)
@leah Definitely. I see potential there as I hate support.

Last I had occasion to use it ( a while ago ) it did the job just fine.  Really, aside from discovery / some formal endpoint requirement on the part of providers, the spec seemed fine.  Just the clients are where it needs work.
Re: Feedback- I've thought about prompting 5% of returning users with a GetSatisfaction feedback form. But, would this possibly annoy users more than the feedback is worth?
(FWIW, it would annoy me. But, I may not be your typical user.)
@leah I asked you about the content rating flag so I didn't get porn on my site randomly. But glad to hear, gives me something else to look at this weekend.

@leah Did anyone ever end up carrying the oembed spec further? I know you + others got it going at Pownce, and I remember a rumor about people trying to get provider discovery built into the spec somehow, but I never heard any more about it.
@mgrdcm what are you building?
At this point, most of the concrete ideas have languished too long in the trench of inaction. But generally small web, non-retail projects.
@nathanwdavis sometimes surveys annoy me but I've actually filled out surveys for companies... it kind of depends on how long the survey is

@leah: The legal stuff has been what has kept me from making the side project to (tiny) startup transition. If it dies due to lack of money, so be it, but if I get the IRS on me or a lawsuit that's a whole other story.
Any advice, other than "hire a lawyer"?
@leah Well, I guess that depends on the state? There is usually liability limits for certain types of corporations based upon the amount of money you have invested, etc.
Basically I think I can make a product an make a little money and even if I'm wrong, no big deal. But yeah, I'm no accountant or lawyer so that unknown and potential liability is the issue.
@mgrdcm unless you think there is something specific that you might have legal trouble with (music stuff seems like an example), I really wouldn't worry about the legal aspects

@mgrdcm At the point that you start selling anything you should spend some money and become a corporation to protect yourself. It is usually cheap (if done online) in comparison to getting sued to oblivion.
Maybe it is that simple. I guess the "don't worry too much until you make enough to be a target, and then you'll have money to fix things" is a strategy.
@johnbellone right... but I think you can still go a long way before having to worry about it :)
@leah The income is where the corporation type matters, LLC vs. S, etc.
@mgrdcm I'd say so.
@leah Sure, no reason to incorporate until you have a product ready to sell. At that point it would depend on the market, who you are selling to, etc. But @mgrdcm was worried about the IRS...
@mgrdcm as long as you pay taxes on your income (in this case, your income is your profit) I think you should be okay?
